title: Boris Johnson could abandon London seat to make sure he is re-elected
text:
Boris Johnson has a fight on his hands to retain his west London constituency (Picture: Reuters)

Boris Johnson could switch seats as he faces a tough fight to hold on to his west London constituency.

The PM has a majority of just 5,034 over Labour for his Uxbridge and South Ruislip seat.

It will take a swing of just over 5% to grab the seat and Jeremy Corbyn’s team are already eyeing it up.

Mr Johnson would face an added difficulty if Nigel Farage’s Brexit Party field a candidate and split the Leave vote.

If an ‘Unseat Boris’ campaign is successful he would be the first premier to lose his seat in an election in modern times.

Ali Milani is Labour’s candidate (Picture: Facebook)

Labour have now claimed that within the next few days, Mr Johnson will announce in the next few days he will stand in a more ‘True Blue’ area.

Mr Corbyn teased he was looking forward to campaigning in the area ‘if the Prime Minister is still the Conservative candidate there at that time.’

The safer seats of Sevenoaks, held by departing Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon, has been touted as a potential.

A Downing Street source has dismissed the rumours as ‘tosh and nonsense.’

A source said: ‘The PM is focused on delivering Brexit and on the needs of the people of Uxbridge. It’s untrue.’

Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn has teased that Mr Johnson might swap seats (Picture: AFP)

Mr Johnson has represented Uxbridge since 2015, where he secured a 10,695 majority.

That halved after the disastrous General Election of 2017, called by then-PM Theresa May.

Labour has chosen 25-year-old Ali Milani as their candidate and the Lib Dems are fielding Dr Liz Evenden-Kenyon.

Mr Johnson’s 5,034 majority is nearly 10% of the electorate and would require the challenger to win all the votes secured by Labour, the Lib Dems, Ukip and the Greens in 2017.

As things stand, there is not a non-aggression pact between the Remain parties.

Richard Tice, chairman of the Brexit Party, has been tipped as a contender in Uxbridge (Picture: PA)

The Brexit Party did not exist in 2017 and could pose a challenge.

Leader Nigel Farage could decide not to field a candidate, making Mr Johnson’s seat relatively safe.

But two people have already been mentioned as potential contenders – Nikki Page and current MEP Richard Tice.

If Mr Johnson wins the election but loses his seat, he would have to step down as Prime Minister.
